Using readings from scenarios, speculative fiction and science fiction the course explores the mutual shaping of fiction, science and technology.

tses.name: Technology-Society: Time
tses.description: Time is a universal human experience, but it presents some profound mysteries. It governs our behaviour on personal, societal and cultural levels. This course will bring together experts from physics, sociology , philosophy, biology, literature and psychology to illuminate our understanding.

wgst.name: Introduction to Feminist Social Transformation
wgst.description: Overview of intersectional feminist debates as well as historical and contemporary theoretical traditions in gender and sexuality studies, critical race studies, and disability studies. Topics include the social construction of femininity, masculinity, and other identifications; Indigenous, decolonial, and transnational feminisms.

wgst.name: Intersectional Identities
wgst.description: Critical examination of the multiple intersections between gender, as a relation of power and social identity, as these intersect with (neo)colonialism, racism, poverty, ableism and heterosexism in a globalized world.

wgst.name: Activism, Feminisms, and Social Justice
wgst.description: A comparative, interdisciplinary examination of feminist activism in the modern era. A range of perspectives and materials are used to examine the objectives, scope, and impact of feminists' efforts to effect social and political change in different historical, cultural, and national settings.

wgst.name: Body Matters: The Politics of Bodies
wgst.description: Introduction to feminist studies of globalization and politics of bodies. Globalization of ideas, cultures, economics and politics, movement of bodies, bodies as spaces for disrupting norms of sex, gender, race, class, ability, sexuality, embodiment and embodied resistance in a globalized world.

wgst.name: Masculinities
wgst.description: Theoretical, experiential, cultural and policy issues around masculinities studies. The complexities of masculinities; the intersections of feminist and masculinity studies. Topics may include hegemonic, racialized, homosexual, and Other(ed) masculinities. Feminist theories and transnational perspectives frame course content and discussions.

wgst.name: Selected Topics in Women’s and Gender Studies
wgst.description: An interdisciplinary analysis of one or more topics in women’s and gender studies.

wgst.name: Gender, Sexuality and Cultural Production
wgst.description: How gender and cultural (re)production (literature, visual/performing arts, social media) and consumption articulate, circulate, and transform each other within economic, political, and social contexts. Emphasis on role, object, processes, and representations.

wgst.name: Theory and Research in Feminist Social Transformation
wgst.description: Interdisciplinary and intersectional approach introducing students to contemporary feminist, Indigenous, decolonial, and transnational theories, issues, conflicts, methodologies, and critiques of prevailing approaches to the construction of knowledge. Themes include, feminist epistemology, ontology, knowledge, and ethics in feminist research.

wgst.name: Feminisms and Transnationalism
wgst.description: Feminist analyses of the diversity of transnational experiences around rights, health, education, motherhood, fathering, work, social media and technological change, among others. Topics may include: migration, environment, wars/conflicts, neocolonialism, diaspora, human trafficking, refugee issues and displaced populations.

wgst.name: Girlhoods
wgst.description: The emerging discipline of girlhood studies; social and cultural constructions of girlhood and categories of difference. Topics may include the commercialization of girlhood, popular culture and girls, negotiating identities, violence, sexualities, agency and activism in a globalizing world.

wgst.name: Gendered Violence
wgst.description: Theories, concepts and contexts of the complex manifestations of gendered violence in the lives of women, men and children globally.

wgst.name: Selected Topics in Women's and Gender Studies
wgst.description: An interdisciplinary analysis of one or more topics in women's and gender studies.

wgst.name: Traversing Feminisms
wgst.description: Interdisciplinary overview of key historical concepts and issues in Women’s and Gender Studies in the areas of theory, epistemology, and research design. Topics will vary from year to year. Provides additional background for students entering Women’s and Gender Studies from other disciplines.

wgst.name: Women’s and Gender Studies Practicum
wgst.description: Experience in research through a combination of classroom seminars and a field placement. Each project will be negotiated individually as a contract between the student, instructor and institutional partner.

wgst.name: Women's and Gender Studies Practicum
wgst.description: Experience in applied feminisms through a combination of classroom seminars and internship. Each project will be negotiated individually as a contract between the student, instructor and institutional partner. Students must complete both the in-class and the internship portion of the course.

wgst.name: Honours Research Project in Women’s and Gender Studies
wgst.description: Students will undertake a major research project on some aspect of women’s and gender studies under the supervision of a faculty member.

wgst.name: Selected Topics in Women’s and Gender Studies
Independent Study
wgst.description: Reading or research course supervised by a faculty member. Written proposal approved by the supervisor must be submitted before last day of course changes. Normally, only 0.5 credit of independent study may be counted in the program.
